Answers.a1: A dried plant from the botany collection – the common poppy
Answers.a3: It is a modern specimen, collected in a field in 2008

WorldQuestion.Question: Why is it displayed like this?

Answers.a1: Drying and pressing this poppy helps preserve it
Answers.a2: Carefully gluing it to paper shows off most of its identifying features
Answers.a3: The label records what it is, where and when it was collected, and by whom

WorldQuestion.Question: Where does it fit in the tree of life?

Answers.a1: It is related to other poppies, shrubs and even small trees in a family called the Papaveraceae
Answers.a2: Two hundred and ten species of Papaveraceae grow worldwide
Answers.a3: Five types of poppy (%3Ci%3EPapaver%3C%2Fi%3E) commonly grow in UK fields

Answers.a1: The tiniest detail on a poppy specimen, or%3Cbr%2F%3Eits label, could lead to new understandings
Answers.a2: Scientists study specimens to answer questions about the natural world, like how biodiversity is changing, and why

Answers.a1: This poppy was collected recently in an%3Cbr%2F%3Eagricultural field – a traditional habitat
Answers.a2: Common poppies were dying out in%3Cbr%2F%3Efields in the mid twentieth century – they%3Cbr%2F%3Ecould not survive the herbicides and%3Cbr%2F%3Efertilisers used in intensive farming
Answers.a3: But some recent changes in farming%3Cbr%2F%3Emethods have allowed common poppies%3Cbr%2F%3Eto return to some fields where they have%3Cbr%2F%3Enot been seen for many years
Answers.a4: Comparing modern specimens with historical specimens and records can help us understand our impact on biodiversity
